title: Muon g-2
content:
{{Short description|Particle physics experiment}}
{{Italic title|string=g}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2022}}
{{Use American English|date=December 2022}}
[[File:Fermilab g-2 (E989) ring.jpg|thumb|The {{mvar|g}} − 2 storage-ring magnet at [[Fermilab]], which was originally designed for the Brookhaven {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment. The geometry allows for a very uniform magnetic field to be established in the ring.]]

'''Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2''' (pronounced "gee minus two") is a [[particle physics]] experiment at [[Fermilab]] to measure the [[anomalous magnetic dipole moment]] of a [[muon]] to a precision of 0.14 [[Parts per million|ppm]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Experiment |type=main page |publisher=Fermilab |lang=en |url=http://muon-g-2.fnal.gov/ |access-date=April 26, 2017}}</ref> which will be a sensitive test of the [[Standard Model]]. It might also provide evidence of the existence of entirely new particles.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Gibney |first=Elizabeth |date=April 13, 2017 |title=Muons' big moment could fuel new physics |journal=Nature |lang=en |volume=544 |issue=7649 |pages=145–146 |doi=10.1038/544145a |pmid=28406224 |bibcode=2017Natur.544..145G|s2cid=4400589 }}</ref>

The muon, like its lighter sibling the electron, acts like a spinning magnet. The parameter known as the "[[g-factor (physics)|{{mvar|g}} factor]]" indicates how strong the magnet is and the rate of its [[gyration]]. The value of {{mvar|g}} is slightly larger than 2, hence the name of the experiment. This difference from 2 (the "anomalous" part) is caused by higher-order contributions from [[quantum field theory]]. In measuring {{mvar|g}} − 2 with high precision and comparing its value to the theoretical prediction, physicists will discover whether the experiment agrees with theory. Any deviation would point to as yet undiscovered subatomic particles that exist in nature.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Collaboration to solve mystery |website=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Experiment |publisher=Fermilab |lang=en |url=http://muon-g-2.fnal.gov/1-muon-g-2-collaboration-to-solve-mystery.html |access-date=April 30, 2017}}</ref>

Four data-taking periods (Run 1,<ref>{{cite press release |title=First results from the Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment at Fermilab |date=March 7, 2021 |publisher=Fermilab |url=https://theory.fnal.gov/events/event/first-results-from-the-muon-g-2-experiment-at-fermilab/}}</ref> Run 2,<ref>{{cite web |title=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 begins second run |website=phys.org |date=March 26, 2019 |url=https://phys.org/news/2019-03-muon-g-.html}}</ref> Run 3, and Run 4{{Citation needed |reason=The citations on Run 1 and Run 2 only talk about those respective runs – it appears they pre-date Run 3. Another citation is needed to support the statement about Runs 3 and later. |date=January 2022}}) have been completed, with Run 5 currently ongoing. The results from the analysis of the Run 1 data were announced and published on April 7, 2021. The physicists reported that results from recent studies involving the particle challenged the Standard Model and, accordingly, may require an updating of currently understood physics.<ref name="NYT-20210407">{{cite news |last=Overbye |first=Dennis |author-link=Dennis Overbye |date=April 7, 2021 |title=Finding from particle research could break known laws of physics |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |quote=It's not the next Higgs boson – yet. But the best explanation, physicists say, involves forms of matter and energy not currently known to science. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/07/science/particle-physics-muon-fermilab-brookhaven.html |access-date=April 7, 2021 }}</ref><ref name="FL-20210407">{{cite press release |last=Marc |first=Tracy |date=April 7, 2021 |title=First results from Fermilab's Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment strengthen evidence of new physics |publisher=[[Fermilab]] |url=https://news.fnal.gov/2021/04/first-results-from-fermilabs-muon-g-2-experiment-strengthen-evidence-of-new-physics/ |access-date=April 7, 2021 }}</ref>

==Timeline==

===Muon ''g'' − 2 at CERN===
[[File:Storage ring.jpg|thumb|The storage ring of the muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment at CERN]]
The first muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiments began at [[CERN]] in 1959 at the initiative of [[Leon Lederman]].<ref name=Farley-2004>{{cite book |last=Farley |first=Francis |author-link=Francis Farley |year=2004 |chapter=The dark side of the muon |editor=Álvarez-Gaumé, Luis |editor-link=Luis Álvarez-Gaumé |title=Infinitely CERN: Memories of fifty years of research, 1954–2004 |pages=38–41 |publisher=Editions Suzanne Hurter |location=Geneva, CH |isbn=978-2-940031-33-7 |oclc=606546795}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Archives of Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment |year=2007 |website=CERN Archive |url=http://library.cern/archives/CERN_archive/guide/experimental_physics/SC/isamuon |access-date=March 4, 2020}}</ref> A group of six physicists formed the first experiment, using the Synchrocyclotron at CERN. The first results were published in 1961,<ref name="Cabibbo1994">{{cite book |last1=Charpak |first1=Georges |author-link1=Georges Charpak |last2=Garwin |first2=Richard L. |last3=Farley |first3=Francis J.M. |author-link3=Francis Farley |last4=Müller |first4=T. |year=1994 |chapter=Results of the {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment |editor1-last=Cabibbo |editor1-first=N. |editor1-link=Nicola Cabibbo |title=Lepton Physics at CERN and Frascati |chapter-url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=QixQ1Khsy_0C|page=34}} |publisher=World Scientific |isbn=9789810220785 |pages=34 ff}}</ref> with a 2% precision with respect to the theoretical value, and then the second ones with this time a 0.4% precision, hence validating the quantum electrodynamics theory.

A second experiment started in 1966 with a new group, working this time with the Proton-Synchrotron, still at CERN. The results were then 25 times more precise than the previous ones and showed a quantitative discrepancy between the experimental values and the theoretical ones, and thus required the physicists to recalculate their theoretical model.
The third experiment, which started in 1969, published its final results in 1979,<ref name="CombleyFarley1981">{{cite journal |last1=Combley |first1=F. |last2=Farley |first2=F.J.M. |last3=Picasso |first3=E. |year=1981 |title=The CERN muon ({{mvar|g}} − 2) experiments |journal=Physics Reports |volume=68 |issue=2 |pages=93–119 |issn=0370-1573 |doi=10.1016/0370-1573(81)90028-4 |bibcode=1981PhR....68...93C |url=http://cds.cern.ch/record/134110}}</ref> confirming the theory with a precision of 0.0007%.
The United States took over the {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment in 1984.<ref name=muong2_CERN_website>{{cite press release |title=Enigma of the muon |publisher=[[European Organization for Nuclear Research]] (CERN) |url=http://public-archive.web.cern.ch/public-archive/en/research/G2-en.html |access-date=July 19, 2018 }}</ref>

===Muon ''g'' − 2 at Brookhaven National Laboratory===
The next stage of muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 research was conducted at the Brookhaven National Laboratory [[Alternating Gradient Synchrotron]]. The experiment was done similarly to the last of the CERN experiments with the goal of having 20 times better precision. The technique involved storing 3.094 [[GeV]] muons in a uniform measured magnetic field and observing the difference of the muon spin precession and rotation frequency via detection of the muon decay electrons. The advance in precision relied crucially on a much more intense beam than was available at CERN and the injection of muons into the storage ring, whereas the previous CERN experiments had injected pions into the storage ring, of which only a small fraction decay into muons that are stored. The experiment used a much more uniform magnetic field using a superferric superconducting storage ring magnet, a passive superconducting inflector magnet, fast muon kickers to deflect the injected muons onto stored orbits, a beam tube NMR trolley that could map the magnetic field in the storage region, and numerous other experimental advances.  The experiment took data with positive and negative muons between 1997 and 2001. Its final result is {{nobr| {{mvar|a}}{{sub|µ}} {{=}} ({{mvar|g}} − 2)/2 {{=}} 11659208.0(5.4)(3.3) × {{10^|−10}} }} obtained by combination of consistent results with similar precision from positive and negative muons.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bennett |first1=G.W. |last2=Bousquet |first2=B. |last3=Brown |first3=H.N. |last4=Bunce |first4=G. |last5=Carey |first5=R.M. |last6=Cushman |first6=P. |last7=Danby |first7=G.T. |last8=Debevec |first8=P.T. |last9=Deile |first9=M. |last10=Deng |first10=H. |collaboration=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Collaboration |display-authors=6 |date=April 7, 2006 |title=Final report of the E821 muon anomalous magnetic moment measurement at BNL |journal=Physical Review D |volume=73 |issue=7 |page=072003 |arxiv=hep-ex/0602035 |bibcode=2006PhRvD..73g2003B |s2cid=53539306 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.73.072003 |url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevD.73.072003}}</ref>

=== Muon ''g'' − 2 at Fermilab ===
[[Fermilab]] is continuing the experiment conducted at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]]<ref name="Farley2004">{{cite journal |last1=Farley |first1=F. |year=2004 |title=The 47 years of muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 |journal=Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics |volume=52 |issue=1 |pages=1–83 |issn=0146-6410 |doi=10.1016/j.ppnp.2003.09.004 |bibcode=2004PrPNP..52....1F}}</ref> to measure the [[anomalous magnetic dipole moment]] of the [[muon]]. The Brookhaven experiment ended in 2001, but ten years later Fermilab acquired the equipment, and is working to make a more accurate measurement (smaller ''[[Confidence interval|σ]]'') which will either eliminate the discrepancy between Brookhaven's results and theory predictions or confirm it as an experimentally observable example of [[physics beyond the Standard Model]].

The magnet was refurbished and powered on in September 2015, and has been confirmed to have the same 1.3 [[Parts per million|ppm]] basic magnetic field uniformity that it had before the move.

As of October 2016 the magnet has been rebuilt and carefully [[shim (magnetism)|shimmed]] to produce a highly uniform magnetic field. New efforts at Fermilab have resulted in a three-fold improved overall uniformity, which is important for the new measurement at its higher precision goal.<ref>{{cite conference |book-title=Proceedings, 12th International Conference on Beauty, Charm, and Hyperons in Hadronic Interactions (BEACH 2016): Fairfax, Virginia, USA, June 12–18, 2016 |conference=XIIth International Conference on Beauty, Charm, and Hyperons in Hadronic Interactions |conference-url=http://beach2016.gmu.edu/ |last=Holzbauer |first=J. L. |date=December 9, 2016 |title=The Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Experiment Overview and Status as of June 2016 |journal=J. Phys. Conf. Ser. |volume=770 |page=012038 |doi=10.1088/1742-6596/770/1/012038 |arxiv=1610.10069 }} {{cite web |url=https://inspirehep.net/record/1495244 |title=alt. source |via=inSPIRE}}</ref>

In April 2017 the collaboration was preparing the experiment for the first production run with protons – to calibrate detector systems. The magnet received its first beam of muons in its new location on May 31, 2017.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Muon magnet's moment has arrived |date=May 31, 2017 |publisher=Fermilab  |url=http://news.fnal.gov/2017/05/muon-magnets-moment-arrived/}}</ref> Data taking was planned to run until 2020.<ref>{{cite conference |book-title= 18th International Workshop on Neutrino Factories and Future Neutrino Facilities Search (NuFact16) Quy Nhon, Vietnam, August 21–27, 2016 |last1=Gohn |first1=W. |display-authors=etal |collaboration=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Collaboration |date=November 15, 2016 |title=The muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment at Fermilab |arxiv=1611.04964 }} {{cite web |url=http://inspirehep.net/record/1498085 |via=inSPIRE |title=alt source}}</ref>

On April 7, 2021, the results of the experiment were published: {{nowrap|1={{math|''a''}}{{sub|µ}} = {{val|0.00116592040|(54)}}}}. The new experimental world-average results announced by the Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 collaboration are: {{mvar|g}}-factor: {{val|2.00233184122|(82)}}, anomalous magnetic moment: {{val|0.00116592061|(41)}}. The combined results from Fermilab and Brookhaven show a difference with theory at a significance of 4.2 sigma, slightly under the 5 sigma (or standard deviations) that particle physicists require to claim a discovery, but still compelling evidence of new physics. The chance that a statistical fluctuation would produce equally striking results is about {{nobr|1 in 40,000.}}<ref name="FL-20210407"/>

==Theory of magnetic moments==
The {{mvar|g}} factor of a charged lepton ([[electron]], [[muon]], or [[Tau (particle)|tau]]) is very nearly 2. The difference from 2 (the "anomalous" part) depends on the lepton, and can be computed quite precisely based on the current [[Standard Model of particle physics]]. Measurements of the electron are in excellent agreement with this computation. The Brookhaven experiment did this measurement for muons, a much more technically difficult measurement due to their short lifetime, and detected a tantalizing, but not definitive, [[Statistical significance|3.7 {{mvar|σ}} discrepancy]] between the measured value and the prediction of the Standard Model ({{val|0.00116592089}} versus {{val|0.0011659180}}).<ref>{{cite press release |title=Physicists publish worldwide consensus of muon magnetic moment calculation |date=June 11, 2020 |publisher=Fermilab |url=https://news.fnal.gov/2020/06/physicists-publish-worldwide-consensus-of-muon-magnetic-moment-calculation/}}</ref>

==Design==
[[File:Littlemove5-hr.jpg|right|thumb|The {{mvar|g}} − 2 ring arriving at its final destination{{snd}}the experimental hall (MC1) at Fermilab{{snd}}on July 30, 2014]]
Central to the experiment is a {{convert|50|foot|m|adj=on}}-diameter [[superconducting magnet]] with an exceptionally uniform magnetic field. This was transported, in one piece, from Brookhaven in [[Long Island]], New York, to Fermilab in the summer of 2013. The move traversed {{convert|3200|mi|km}} over 35 days,<ref>{{cite news |first1=David |last1=Hertzog |first2=Lee |last2=Roberts |date=October 27, 2014 |title=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 storage ring starts a new life |website=CERN Courier |lang=en-GB |url=http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cern/58931 |access-date=April 26, 2017}}</ref> mostly on a barge down the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] and through [[Mobile, Alabama]], to the [[Tennessee–Tombigbee Waterway]] and then briefly on the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]]. The initial and final legs were on a special truck traveling closed highways at night.

[[File:PbF2 Crystal SIPM.png|left|thumb|Sample 25 mm × 25 mm × 140 mm [[lead(II) fluoride|PbF{{sub|2}}]] crystals (bare and wrapped in Millipore paper) are pictured together with a 16 channel monolithic Hamamatsu SiPM.]]

===Detectors===
The magnetic moment measurement is realized by 24 electromagnetic [[Calorimeter (particle physics)|calorimetric detectors]], which are distributed uniformly on the inside of the storage ring. The calorimeters measure the energy and time of arrival (relative to the injection time) of the decay positrons (and their count) from the muon [[Particle decay|decay]] in the storage ring. After a muon decays into a positron and two neutrinos, the positron ends up with less energy than the original muon. Thus, the magnetic field curls it inward where it hits a segmented [[lead(II) fluoride]] (PbF{{sub|2}}) calorimeter read out by silicon [[Photomultiplier|photo-multipliers]] (SiPM).<ref name="TDR">{{cite report |last1=Grange |first1=J. |last2=Guarino |first2=V. |last3=Winter |first3=P. |last4=Wood |first4=K. |last5=Zhao |first5=H. |last6=Carey |first6=R.M. |last7=Gastler |first7=D. |last8=Hazen |first8=E. |last9=Kinnaird |first9=N. |collaboration=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Collaboration |display-authors=6 |date=January 27, 2015 |title=Muon ({{mvar|g}} − 2) Technical Design Report |arxiv=1501.06858 |bibcode=2015arXiv150106858G }} {{cite web |url=http://inspirehep.net/record/1341289 |title=alt. source |via=inSPIRE}}</ref>

The [[Particle detector|tracking detectors]] register the trajectory of the positrons from the muon decay in the storage ring. The tracker can provide a muon [[electric dipole moment]] measurement, but not directly the magnetic moment measurement. The main purpose of the tracker is to measure the muon beam profile, as well as resolution of pile-up of events (for reduction of the systematic uncertainty in the calorimeter measurement).<ref name=TDR/>

[[File:Tracker g-2.jpg|thumb|One of the 4 rows of 32 straws is shown. A straw (length of 100 mm, and diameter of 5 mm) acts like an [[ionisation chamber]] filled with 1:1 [[argon]]:[[ethane]], with a central cathode wire at +1.6 kV.]]

===Magnetic field===
To measure the magnetic moment to [[Parts-per notation|ppb]] level of precision requires a uniform average magnetic field to be of the same level precision. The experimental goal of {{mvar|g}} − 2 is to achieve an uncertainty level on the magnetic to 70 ppb averaged over time and muon distribution. A uniform field of {{val|1.45|ul=T}} is created in the storage ring using superconducting magnets, and the field value will be actively mapped throughout the ring using an [[NMR]] probe on a mobile trolley (without breaking the vacuum). Calibration of the trolley is referenced to the [[Larmor frequency]] of a proton in a spherical water sample at a reference temperature (34.7 °C), and is cross-calibrated to a novel [[helium-3]] magnetometer.<ref name=TDR/>

===Data acquisition===
An essential component of the experiment is the [[data acquisition]] (DAQ) system, which manages the data flow from the detector electronics. The requirement for the experiment is to acquire raw data at a rate of 18 GB/s. This is accomplished by employing parallel data-processing architecture using 24 high-speed [[Graphics processing unit|GPUs]] (NVIDIA Tesla K40) to process data from 12 bit waveform digitisers. The set-up is controlled by the MIDAS DAQ software framework. The DAQ system processes data from 1296 calorimeter channels, 3 straw tracker stations, and auxiliary detectors (e.g. entrance muon counters). The total data output of the experiment is estimated at 2 [[byte|PB]].<ref>{{cite conference |last=Gohn |first=W. |collaboration=Muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 Collaboration |display-authors=etal |date=November 15, 2016 |title=Data acquisition with GPUs: The DAQ for the muon {{mvar|g}} − 2 experiment at Fermilab |book-title=Proceedings, 38th International Conference on High Energy Physics (ICHEP 2016): Chicago, Illinois, USA, August 3–10, 2016 |page=174 |arxiv=1611.04959 |doi=10.22323/1.282.0174 |bibcode=2016arXiv161104959G }} {{cite web |url=http://inspirehep.net/record/1498145 |title=alt. source |via=inSPIRE}}</ref>
